title: Synthetic Recap
body:
CLEVELAND (AP) – On a night where offense was a precious commodity, one man staged a historic solo performance. Glenn Robinson, "The Big Dog," unleashed a masterpiece, single-handedly dismantling the Cleveland Cavaliers and carrying the Milwaukee Bucks to a gritty 90-82 victory in 1997.

In an era defined by physical, low-scoring battles, Robinson’s performance was nothing short of seismic. He poured in a game-high 44 points, a staggering figure in an 82-point team effort. While teammates struggled to find their rhythm, Robinson was a study in relentless efficiency, accounting for over half of the Bucks' total offense. Every time Cleveland threatened to close the gap, Robinson answered with a cold-blooded jumper or a powerful drive to the basket, his will proving indomitable.

The Cavaliers, led by 21 points from Terrell Brandon, simply had no answer. Shawn Kemp, typically a force in the paint, was held to a quiet 10 points and 8 rebounds, his influence muted by the singular focus on Robinson’s onslaught. Cleveland’s defense tried everything, but Robinson was unstoppable, turning the Gund Arena into his personal showcase.

This was more than just a win; it was a declaration. Robinson’s 44-point eruption wasn't merely a high-scoring game; it was a carry-job for the ages, a testament to one player's ability to transcend a defensive struggle and author a victory through sheer, unadulterated scoring brilliance. On this night, the game’s story was simple: Glenn Robinson, and everyone else.
